segments.text: with you if we donate this to the oral history collection at Texas A&M?
Yes, it is.
Okay.
Which of the forces were you in?
I was in the United States Army.
And what division and unit?
I was attached to the 2 Field Force.
It's Roman numeral 2 Field Force.
And I was assigned to the
Two Field Force Artillery, which was a brigade-sized artillery unit.
Okay, and what was your title?
I was the legal officer for the artillery brigade.
Okay, and what was your rank?
First Lieutenant.
And what dates were you in Vietnam?
May the 31st, 1970 through...
January the 19th, 1971.
Where were you stationed?
I was stationed at a place called Plantation.
It was right outside of Long Ben, which was a large United States military installation, and right by the city, Benoit City, which was a Vietnamese city, town.
How did you end up in Vietnam?
Were you drafted or did you enlist?
No, I was ROTC at the University of Texas.
Okay.
How much did you know about the war before you left?
Oh, probably not any more than anyone else that watched TV and read the newspaper at that time.
I really didn't keep up with it a lot.
I would watch TV and read the newspaper, and that's about all I know about it.
Do you think it affected you that you entered the war after the Tet Offensive and all the news coverage of that?
Do you think you would have had a different perspective before that?
Oh, I don't think so.
I think probably the Tet Offensive would have,
It might have changed my outlook a little bit on Vietnam and serving in Vietnam.
Probably would have been more of an incentive to be there.
Okay.
When you left, what training were you given?
We had what was called RVN training, Republic of Vietnam training.
It was basically

orientation on the country and the culture of the country, something about the people, a little bit about staying alive and it was a week training, one week training at Fort Hood where I was stationed when I left.
Did you know any Vietnamese at all or just a brief kind of overview of their culture?
Not really.
I didn't know very much about Vietnam at all when I went there.
What was your first perception of Vietnam?
Well, it was, it appeared to me to be a very backward country.
It was very flat where I was.
Dirty.
with a Vietnamese person?
I was, I shared an office with, my office was in a building that I shared with, with the civil affairs officer for our brigade and he, he had a Vietnamese, he had a counter, his counterpart with the
the Republic of Vietnam, the Army of the Republic of Vietnam, was a Sergeant Ahn.
That was my first encounter on a personal basis with any Vietnamese.
He spoke English very well.
He was very polite.
Really a nice guy.
Was it hard to adjust to daily life in Vietnam?
Not really.
We worked all the time.
We worked seven days a week from seven in the morning until five in the evening.
So there was, you know, you were just busy.
You were working all the time, so it really wasn't too hard to adjust.
I was not out in the field, so I was not out in the field a lot, so I was really in an office type job and really didn't have much
problem adjusting to just doing my job.
Do you think it was hard on the people in the field because they weren't always busy?
You know, fighting was maybe one day out of a month or whatever.
I think it was a little different when I was there.
I think that war was winding down.
And it probably, there probably was some boredom and some feelings of uselessness
helplessness because the people are not busy every day.
They, you know, they may be doing things that will make work type activities or tasks.
As a legal officer, what were your duties?
I prosecuted
For the brigade, we were a special court martial jurisdiction, which meant that the commanding officer of the brigade was a one-star general, or he was actually a full colonel general designate.
And he had authority to sentence up to six months in the confinement in a stockade.

So I prosecuted primarily those cases, handled the administrative portion or supervised administrative portion of the court-martials at the special court-martial level, and advised the commanding officer of our brigade on the legal affairs of the brigade and the prosecution of the cases within his court-martial jurisdiction.
What did you find was the major difference between a court martial situation as opposed to the normal court system in the United States?
Basically there's not any real difference between the two systems that follow essentially the same rules of evidence and same rules of procedure as the federal system.
I would say that the biggest difference during the period of time that I was in the service was the
refusal or the choice by the accused not to use a jury trial but to elect to be tried by military judges and sentenced by military judges as opposed to selecting a jury made up of military personnel.
Most of the people chose to be tried and if they were convicted, sentenced by military judges.
What type of charges did you bring against the soldiers?

Oh, they ranged everywhere from I tried one negligent homicide case where a guy accidentally shot McGillie's best friend to all types of drug possession and use charges, marijuana, heroin, and military offenses such as insubordination, sleeping on guard duty,

So they really range from failure to salute, fairly insignificant type violations of the military code of justice, to fairly significant charges, any of which could have been a general court-martial, which would be an unlimited jurisdiction, but for various reasons were tried at the special court-martial level, which had a limited sentencing jurisdiction.
But I ran nearly the entire gamut of military violations.
Were they given any, I guess, special treatment because of their psychological state during the war?
I don't think so.
I think there was probably a relaxing of the military...

rules that is the fewer and fewer people were ever charged or tried or court-martialed, I guess, for military violations like failure to salute or insubordination or improper uniform or those kinds of things.
Those rules were relaxed in Vietnam substantially.
I think most of the offenses that were tried dealt with
things that were perceived as something that might get you or your fellow soldiers killed, drug offenses, and weapons violations primarily, or somebody got hurt carelessly using a weapon.
How big do you think the drug problem was during Vietnam?
During the period of time I was there, it was extensive.
It was readily available.

The post I was on had a seven foot or seven or eight foot chain link fence around it with barbed wire around the top of it and Constantino wire around the bases out several feet and the Vietnamese kids would come up to the fence and throw marijuana over in a five pound plastic bag.
what the price of it was, but it was relatively inexpensive, but it was very easy to get.
Do you think the North Vietnamese contributed to it and helped the distribution?
I don't have any real proof of that.
I have an opinion that they probably did.
I think it was psychologically to their advantage to make the drugs readily available, plus the fact they, although it was illegal to have,
United States currency in Vietnam.
Everyone was issued military script.
Some people still had currency, and if you could get, say, a $50 bill would buy a lot more than $50 of military script of anything, whether it was drugs or contraband or anything of that nature.
Primarily the North Vietnamese and the Viet Cong would be taking the United States currency
to buy weapons.
Why was there a drug problem in this war as opposed to other wars?
It may have been a sign of our time.
We may have had a drug problem not only in Vietnam but in the United States.
or the beginning of a drug problem in the United States altogether.
I think that it probably was not a popular war.
I'm not sure that would contribute a lot to the use of drugs in Vietnam, as opposed to just the availability and relatively inexpensive
availability of the drugs in Vietnam.
We had many guest speakers in my class, and I noticed that those in the latter part of the war noticed a big drug problem while the ones at the first part of the war barely saw any.
Do you think that was true, or is it just where they were stationed in their perception?
No, I think that's probably true.
Understanding I was only there to see it for a 10-month period.

at a time which I felt, and I believe the war was winding down, a lack of military operations, a lack of actual day-to-day combat or military operations or maneuver time on the hands of the people over there.
I think that that's a winding, a...
result or characteristic of the winding down of the war.
Idleness.
What effect do you think drugs had on military operations?

Well, I don't have any doubt that if you've got someone that's using drugs during a military operation, it's got to affect his ability to perform his job as it would anyone, whether you're a truck driver or you're
you're driving a tank or trying to, in my case, fire an artillery piece.
I think it will affect and did affect some of the military operations.
I think the problem was more not during actual operations that people were using it, but in their
free time, if you will, when they were not on an operation and they were on some kind of drug.
Do you think the drug problem affected minorities any more or less than the white soldiers?
I really can't answer that.
I don't think so.
Let me say, I did not perceive that you had a greater problem among blacks or Hispanics than you had among whites.
I think we handled the process just as many all races.
I don't think there was any line drawn between one particular minority or our minorities and anyone else.
Did you see any cases of racial tension?
A few.
I think it was primarily the blacks felt like they were being discriminated against.
It was a perception that I had and probably from the facts that they felt they did not get, or not that they did not get the good jobs, but they got the bad jobs.
In a lack of acceptance of military discipline, I think that was part of the problem that created some of the racial tension that I saw.
In some cases,
We found out that the North Vietnamese dropped information to the black soldiers about, you know, you were enslaved and similar situations are going on in Vietnam.
Did you see any of that?
I did not see any of that literature.
I mean, I believe that to be true because I know that that's what the civil affairs companies for the United States Army did over North Vietnam.
They dropped leaflets all the time, so that was part of their job.
I didn't see it in that literature, but I don't have any doubt that it probably existed.
Okay, what did the Army do for those with a drug addiction?
Well, they probably really didn't do very much during the period of time that I was there.
I think that there was a recognition back in the United States that a problem and a

huge problem was existing as a result of soldiers coming back to the United States with drug habits that they were not able to support in the United States just because of the cost, the difference in the cost of the drugs.
And I know that there was an effort to counsel and educate and discipline
for drug use and abuse.
While I was there, I served on a particular committee that was made up of a doctor.
I can't think of his name.
Not his name, his title.
He was a preacher.
I can't think of it, Paige.
Chaplain?
Chaplain.
He was a United States chaplain.

and me as a lawyer, and we went to the various firing batteries in my brigade and tried to counsel and talk with and educate the soldiers about the use of drugs and the problems that they can encounter looking at it from a medical standpoint, a legal standpoint, and a religious standpoint.
And I know that program was instituted while I was in Vietnam and carried out.
We did do that.
I don't know how successful it was, but we did do it.
What sentences did you give those?
Of course, like I said earlier, I had a very limited jurisdiction.
Six months confinement in a stockade was the maximum that the jurisdiction I served in could

administer, most of it would be, and that was one of the reasons that people took the military judges to impose sentences as opposed to military juries because they tended to be lesser sentences than would have been or were in fact administered by the jury.
So most of the offenses would range from two to three months
for drug possession primarily.
And it all depended on whether this was a first or second offense.

And two to three months of confinement with a loss of two-thirds pay for that period of time for a first offender with a hard drug, heroin, marijuana offender probably wouldn't get maybe 30 days, two months, depending on a lot of it, depending on how much they had.
And
But that was left strictly up to the judge.
I really had no input into it.
He made that decision.
Which drug do you think was the worst in Vietnam?
Well, I think the heroin was, obviously, was the worst, the most dangerous, and was readily available.
It was cheap, and it was a lot stronger, a more pure grade of heroin than they were
my understanding that people were able to buy once they got back to the United States.
It was not cut nearly as much as what was sold on the streets in the United States back then.
What effect do you think dealing with all these drug problems has on you today?
I mean, do you take a stronger stance against drugs or maybe legalization of drugs?
Oh, I don't know.
I'm probably more intolerant of drug and drug abuse than I was
Well, then I might otherwise have been, although I doubt it.
I'm just not very tolerant of drug users or drug sellers.
What percentage do you think were caught?
Caught using?
Mm-hmm, caught using drugs.
A very small percentage.
There were too many people over there.
There were half a million men over there
one time, and you just didn't handle very many of them.
One percent, two percent.
You said you had a limited field experience.
When did you have to go?
I went to, we had firing batteries that were stationed in various places in the field.
When I arrived in Vietnam, the

Cambodian, it was right in the middle of the Cambodian invasion, so our firing batteries were up on the Cambodian border supporting the Americans, which were over there for 30 days, but they pulled out right at the end of May.
But the ARVN stayed up in Cambodia and our batteries supported up there.
It was a lot easier for me to get out to the batteries than it was to bring
or people in for me to counsel or that nature.
So I wouldn't say that I went to the field a lot, but I was out maybe weekly to one battery or the other during the time that I was there.
Sometimes we would go in Jeeps or trucks, but most of the time we flew in Alconca.
Did you ever see any combat?
No.
Not to my knowledge.
What was the hardest case for you to try?
I think the negligent homicide case that I had over there.
The kid just accidentally, you know, said they were sitting around in a hooch one night shooting a bull, and he pulled his .45 and killed his best friend.
It was a tough case to try.
What happened to the kid?
He was found guilty and got six months in the stockade, which was the maximum he could have gotten under the special court martial jurisdiction.
I think he was fortunate that he was, that the general court martial jurisdiction elected not to process him at that level because he could have gotten life.
Well, probably not life, 10 years.
Do you think he ever got over it from being on, or was he greatly affected?
No, he was greatly affected.
I don't remember the kid well.
I remember he was from a Midwestern state, Missouri or somewhere like that.
Average intelligence, but not a bad kid at all.
Young, 19.
And I think he was affected.
I don't know that he was affected so much by Vietnam as he was the fact that he had killed somebody.
What effect do you think the age, well, the difference in age, you'll say, between Vietnam and World War II had on the cases you tried and the numbers?
Oh, I think that I'm not sure there was.
There is a difference in age between the soldiers in World War II and in Vietnam.
And this is my own perception.
I perceive war to be a young thing.

young men's game that it's easier to take 17, 18, 19, 20 year old kids and give them a rifle and send them off to war there they see a challenge to it as opposed to someone a little bit older that may not quite see that as being a glorious activity.
I think that
The age differential, I'm not sure that there really was one.
Or there ever has been.
I think young people sometimes tend to do dumb things.
Whether that's drug abuse or running up a mountain or a hill with a rifle, screaming at somebody, that's another thing.
I don't think there's an age problem.
I don't think it was an age
that would cause more people to be processed or court-martialed in Vietnam than there would have been in World War II just because of the age.
I don't think there's an age difference, really.
Do you think you had a different perception because you had a family and you were older as opposed to a young soldier?
And what do you think the difference was?
No, I think I did.
I very definitely think I had a different view.
I was not going to take any chances if I could keep from it.
And by that, I meant I did not want to be out in the field with a rifle and walking around in the rice paddies or whatever trying to find Charlie.
I think there were several people
that served in Vietnam that truly enjoyed it.
They liked it.
I had a fellow that was in one of the units that I had jurisdiction over that I tried to recruit to come into my office.
He was a black guy from South Texas.
He had a college education and he would have made a very good legal clerk.

job that I wanted him to do for me but he was a duster commander he had a duster which was a trapped vehicle that rode road guard for convoys and he liked to do that and he he would not even consider making the change
What type of cases went up to the general court martial as opposed to your level?
Second offenders.
Cases that involved a homicide of some kind, generally.
And anything that dealt with a breach of security.
In the military system, any offense can be handled at any level.
So they all can be up there.
It just depends on whether you want to.

The general court martial authority wants to handle those offenses at that level because of what he believes to be a serious problem as opposed to something that ought to be handled at a lower level because of special circumstances.
Most of the cases that went up would be second offenders, people that were destined to be removed from the military with some kind of less than honorable discharge.
If they get a general court-martial, then they were removed with dishonorable discharge or some sort of discharge that would be less than honorable.
How long would it take to get your case tried?
Really not very long.
I could get most of my cases ready from the time that the charges come in from the field and are processed within 30 to 45 days.
So much faster than the court system here.
Yes.
We probably didn't handle as many cases as they handled here, but we can get them ready for you.
A lot of it was depending on the availability of the witnesses.
If they were in a firing battery way up north somewhere, it was a little difficult to get them in.
On a few occasions, I went to the field and tried to get to my court reporter and to the defense counsel and tried the case in the field if the military judge would do it.
That was a rare occurrence, but sometimes when you had a lot of witnesses, it was a whole lot easier to move the courtroom to the field than it was to bring the witnesses back for a trial.
Okay.
I guess changing subjects.
What did you do after 5 o'clock in Vietnam?
I generally went to the...
back to my room and change clothes.
I really didn't change clothes.
I kept the same clothes.
I went to either the officer's open mess or the officer's club for dinner and I watched a movie almost every night.
Did they bring in American movies?
Just the ones that were showing or a lot of classics?
No, mostly they would have mostly
current movies, first-line, first-run movies.
We watch movies almost every night.
Do you enjoy movies now?
Yeah, very much.
Still?
Have you seen a lot of movies about Vietnam?
I've seen one or two.
Full metal jacket.
What did you think of it?
No, it wasn't full metal jacket, it was the other one.
Platoon?
Platoon, I saw Platoon.
It's kind of like a lot of movies that you see.
I think probably at some time during the 15 years that the United States was in Vietnam, those things happened.
I doubt very seriously that they happened to that one platoon, that all those things happened to that one platoon.
They condensed all of the horrible things or the good things that they can show in movies into an hour and 45 minutes and happening to one small group of people.
It didn't bother me.
It didn't affect me.
I looked at it as just a movie.
How did you think they dealt with drug use?
Do you think it was very accurate?
I'm not sure I remember how they dealt with it in the movie.
Do you remember?
I think it was mostly in their hootches or whatever and no one was really caught and a lot of young kids.
No, I think that's probably true.
That's probably accurate.
That's really what I was trying to describe to you a few minutes ago when I said I really didn't think that they used it in the field but when they would be back in their base.
as probably a method of escape.
What was the climate of Vietnam like?
It's tropical.
It's very hot, very humid.
And during the rainy season, it rains every day harder than you can believe.
And then during the dry season, it stays dry and hot and gets dusty.
But it's hot all the time now.
Was that hard to learn to deal with?
No, it really wasn't.
Once, at least for me, once I acclimated myself to the change from a rather dry climate to a tropical, subtropical climate, it wasn't any problem.
How much do you know about the military strategy in action?
Did you ever learn anything about it while you were there, or did they keep you all totally... No, not really.
I wasn't involved tactically in what was going on in Vietnam, so I didn't go to briefings, to the tactical briefings.

I had my own private briefing with the general that was, the colonel that was in charge of our unit, and I didn't sit in on regular staff meetings, although I was on his staff, so I really didn't have any input or
access to the tactical part of what was going on and other than what I read in the newspaper are left here on the radio.
Did you get a military newspaper?
We got a old, it was a, I guess you could call it a military newspaper.
It was two or three pages of kind of what's factual data of what's going on.
So it was very screened?
Yes.
Well, I assume it was.
I'm assuming it was
I'm not saying it was censored, but I think they put whatever they wanted to in it.
Did you ever hear about the anti-war protesters while you were in Vietnam?
Oh, yes.
We had access to American television.
We watched American television available, so we watched the news.
How did you feel towards these people?
Oh, I probably was...
I probably had some ill feeling for them that I didn't like, didn't really like them.
I thought they were probably not patriotic, maybe cowards.
How did your wife feel about them?
Hmm.
I think she probably felt about the same way that I did about them.
That we really didn't, we don't have much respect.
We did not then and I don't today have much respect for those type, the people that were demonstrating and draft dodging and going to Canada or whatever.
I'm not saying that I hold anything against folks that joined the National Guard.
or just drew a lucky number and didn't get drafted.
That's part of the luck of the deal.
But I just don't have much respect for those two.
Should we have allowed the media free access in Vietnam?
Sure.
I think so.
I don't know.
I felt like they had pretty free access to what was going on in Vietnam.
And I certainly don't see any reason to keep them out.
Should we have allowed other civilians that weren't media, such as, you know, like Jane Fonda, whenever that's the most famous, but a lot of the anti-war protesters?
I think it's, you know, it's not good for morale to have someone who had some kind of national reputation in the United States over supporting the North Vietnamese.
I don't think it's good.
It is good for morale, but I don't really think that you can keep it out or you ought to keep them out.
If they want to go over there and do that, that's fine.
Maybe the remedy is something other than stopping them from going.
Let them stay.
Don't let them come back.
What effect did television have on the war since this was the first televised war?
I think it had significance.
I don't own the war.
It had a significant effect on the people that were involved in it.

They knew more about what was going on in this war than participants in any other war, I suppose, on a daily basis because you could turn the TV on and watch the 6 o'clock news or the 5.30 national news broadcast and find out more about what was going on in Vietnam, around Vietnam, and in the United States because of Vietnam.
Probably...
Well, not probably than any other war that I know of.
What perception did the soldiers or you have of the different presidents?
I guess for that time it was Nixon.
Because, I mean, did television cloud that?
I got to think about that.
Was Nixon the president when I was there?
When did Johnson go there?
Sixty-eight.
Well, I guess that we felt, I felt, let me just say what I felt.
I felt like that Vietnam was a war that could have been won had we wanted to win the war.
I don't know too much about what the political risk for
an all out invasion, an all out effort to win that war would have caused around the world, if any, might not have caused anything.
And I really felt like it was a situation where, had we have not been so concerned about our worldwide image and even maybe our image back at home,
that war could have been over in six months to a year.
So you think we should have been in Vietnam?
I don't have an opinion whether we should have been there or we should not have been there.
At the time, it was something that I had volunteered myself to do.

decided, I made the decision when I joined, when I started in college, to join the ROTC knowing full well that when I got out of there, the chances, out of the school, the chances were better than 50-50 that I would wind up in Vietnam.
I looked at it as my job.
And I went because I was told to go.
I really made no judgment about
whether we should have or should not have been there.
If I look back on it now, the way we handled it, it probably was a mistake to have been there.
Whether it affects our national security, whether it would have affected our national security back then, or some significant national interest that we had in preserving Vietnam,
I really don't have a very good feeling for the fact that we were over there.
Did that answer that?
